The Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center of Northwestern University Chicago, IL 60611, USA
Pancreatic Cancer Translational Research Group, School of Medical Sciences University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia

Abstract.AbstractText: Pancreatic cancer is characterised by a prominent desmoplastic/stromal reaction. It is now known that pancreatic stellate cells (PSCs) are the principal source of fibrosis in the stroma and interact closely with cancer cells to create a tumor facilitatory environment that stimulates local tumor growth and distant metastasis. Pancreatic fibrosis is initiated when PSCs become activated and undergo morphological and, more importantly, functional changes so that the rate of extracellular matrix (ECM) deposition exceeds the rate of ECM degradation in the gland. It is now well established that pancreatic cancer cells activate PSCs leading to increased fibrosis. This chapter summarises recent advances in our understanding of the role of fibrosis in pancreatic cancer, with particular reference to the central role played by pancreatic stellate cells. An improved knowledge of PSC biology has the potential to provide an insight into pathways that may be therapeutically targeted to inhibit PSC activation, thereby inhibiting the development of fibrosis in pancreatic cancer and interrupting stellate cell - cancer cell interactions so as to retard cancer progression.

Section.SectionTitle: The biology of pancreatic stellate cells
Role of pancreatic stellate cells in pancreatic fibrosis
The role of cancer-stellate cell interactions in tumor progression
Role of pancreatic stellate cells and fibrosis in epithelial- mesenchymal transition
Targeting pancreatic stellate cell mediated fibrosis: A potential therapy
